questions.text: What is the use of this instrument?
questions.solution:
The given image is that of a Leech-Wilkinson cannula. It is used to inject dye in hysterosalpingography. 

The following images show the cannula placed in the cervix for the procedure:


Other cannula used for the same purpose is the Rubin’s cannula which is shown below:

questions.text:
Identify the true statements about the device shown in the image when compared to endotracheal intubation.

A. Increased risk of gastric aspiration

B. More secure airway

C. Requires muscle relaxants

D. Does not require neck mobility

E. Less invasive
questions.solution:
The given image shows a laryngeal mask airway (LMA), which is indicated in cases with difficult airways. LMA is a less secure airway when compared to endotracheal intubation and it does not require muscle relaxants.

LMA is used for airway management as a temporary, life-saving measure in patients with difficult ventilation. Difficult ventilation can be either due to difficult airways, unavailability, or difficulty in mask ventilation and intubation.

Advantages of LMA:

  • Less invasive as compared to tracheal tubes.
  • Lesser bronchospasm as compared to tracheal tubes 
  • It partially protects the larynx from pharyngeal secretions.
  • Useful in difficult intubations
  • Less trauma to teeth and pharynx
  • Muscle relaxation is not required
  • Neck mobility is not required 

Disadvantages:

  • Increased risk of gastrointestinal aspiration
  • Less safe in prone or jack-knife positions
  • Less secure airway
  • Greater risk of a gas leak and pollution

Related Pearl: Indications and contraindications of Laryngeal mask airway (LMA)

Indication:

  • Difficult airway management during cardiopulmonary resuscitation.
  • In emergency where intubation & mask ventilation is not possible. 
  • For minor surgeries, where Anesthetist wants to avoid intubation. 
  • As a conduit for bronchoscopes, small size tubes, gum elastic bougies.

Contraindications:

  • Oropharyngeal abscess or mass
  • Poor mouth opening 
  • Conditions with high risk of aspiration:
    • Hiatus hernia
    • Pregnancy
    • Full stomach patients who are vulnerable to go in bronchospasm
    • Low pulmonary compliance (eg. Obesity)
    • Peak inspiratory pressure > 30 cm of H2O. 


 

Related Pearl: Different sizes of the laryngeal mask airway

Mask size Patient Size  Weight (kg) Cuff Volume (mL)
1 Infant <5 2-4
1.5 Infant 5-10 upto 7
2 Child 10-20 upto 10
2.5 Child 20-30 upto 14
3 Small Adult 30-50 upto 20
4 Normal adult(women) 50-70 upto 30 
5 Normal adult >70 30-40
6 Adults >100 50

questions.text: Identify the gas represented by the pin index shown in the image below.
questions.solution:
The pin index of 2,5 is specific for oxygen.

Pin Index Safety System (PISS) is a safety measure to prevent incorrect cylinder attachment.

Related Pearl: Pin index safety system (PISS):

Note:

  • Mixtures of CO2 and O2 with more than 7% CO2: 1,6
  • Mixtures of CO2 and O2 with less than 7% CO2: 2,6

questions.text: Identify the instrument shown in the image and the site at which it is used for taking samples.

choices.text: Ayre's spatula used at the squamocolumnar junction
Ayre's spatula used at the endocervix
Cytobrush used at the squamocolumnar junction

questions.solution:
The instrument in the given image is a cytobrush which is used to take samples from the endocervix for a Pap smear. Ayre’s spatula is used to take samples from the squamocolumnar junction.

The instruments used for a pap smear are summarized in the image below.


The Pap/ Papanicolaou test is used for screening cervical neoplasia. The ideal time for the collection of a sample is around ovulation but can be done at any other time as well. 24-48 hours prior to the test, patients should abstain from vaginal intercourse, douching, tampon use, and intravaginal medications. The Pap smear should be obtained before vaginal examination, because the fingers may remove the desquamated cervical cells and give a false-negative report.

The patient is put in a dorsal position and Cusco’s self-retaining speculum is introduced. The squamocolumnar junction is identified and scraped with Ayre’s spatula. Endocervix is scarped with a cytobrush. Samples are spread separately on 2 different glass slides. The slide is immediately fixed using 95% ethyl alcohol. After fixing the slide for 30 minutes, it is air dried and stained with Pap stain or short stain.

questions.text: Identify the following instrument.
questions.solution:
The instrument shown is a harmonic scalpel. It is an instrument that uses ultrasonic energy to cut tissues while simultaneously coagulating them.

The scalpel vibrates in the 20000–50000 Hz range and cuts through tissues, achieving hemostasis by sealing vessels and tissues by means of protein denaturation using vibration rather than heat.

The different modes of electrosurgery are as follows:

  • Cutting is a mode of diathermy/electrosurgery. The cut current is a low-voltage, continuous waveform. Cutting occurs when sufficient heat is applied to the tissue to cause cell water to explode into steam.
  • Coagulation is the sealing of blood vessels. In coagulation, a heating effect leads to cell death by dehydration and protein denaturation.
  • A blend is a combination of cutting and coagulation.
  • Fulguration refers to the destructive coagulation of tissues with charring. The diathermy matching is set to coagulation and a higher effective voltage is used to make larger sparks jump an air gap thus fulgurating the tissues.

The bipolar cautery contains two tips, unlike unipolar cautery, which has only one tip. The current flows between these two tips, and hence, it does not need a return electrode, unlike the unipolar cautery.

LigaSure vessel sealing system (shown below) is a bipolar apparatus for sealing vascular tissue. It applies a high coaptive pressure during the generation of tissue temperature under 1000°C, hydrogen cross-links are first ruptured and then renatured, resulting in a vascular seal that has high tensile strength.

Related Pearl: Diathermy/Cautery:

Features Monopolar Bipolar
Flow of current

Cautery pencil –> tissue –> cautery pad –> machine/ground

Hence more chance of burns

Only between tips of the instrument

Hence less chance of burns
Modes

Cutting – Low voltage, high amplitude, continuous waveforms

Coagulation – Alternate waveforms (Bursts)

Dessication – Low power

Fulguration – High power

 Only coagulation
Dissipation

More thermal dissipation of current

Hence can cause damage to nerves and other vital structures

Less lateral dissipation of current

Hence safer in procedures closer to vital structures

questions.text: A 45-year-old male patient with COVID-19 infection develops shortness of breath and is brought to the hospital. His SpO2 increases from 81% to 83% on administering oxygen via facemask at 10 L/min. The decision to deliver oxygen using the device shown below is made. What is its oxygen delivery rate?
questions.solution:
The equipment shown in the image is high-flow nasal cannula. It delivers oxygen at 40-60 L/min. This patient has persistent hypoxia after an adequate trial of standard oxygen therapy and should be started on high-flow nasal cannula oxygen therapy. 

High flow nasal cannula is a mode of respiratory support used in the management of acute respiratory failure. It delivers humidified gas via the nasal cannula at high flow rates.

  • HFNC can deliver oxygen at 40 L/min, 37°C, and 99.9% relative humidity.
  • The high-flow oxygen is delivered directly to the nasopharynx. This produces FiO2 equal to that delivered by traditional mask devices.
  • The benefits of HFNC include reduced work of breathing, improved gas exchange by nasopharyngeal dead-space washout, and decreased energy required to humidify and heat respiratory gases.

The HFNC equipment shown in the image below uses a heated humidifier (named PMH200), a nasal cannula (No. 2), and a ventilator (brand: vivo30).


Other options:

Oxygen delivery devices Flow rate (liter/min)  Approximate FiO2
Nasal cannula  1-6  0.24-0.44 
Simple face mask  6-10 0.40-0.60
Non-rebreathing mask 10-15 0.90-1.00 
Venturi mask  2-15  0.24-0.60

 


The image below shows a non-rebreathing mask.

questions.text: The Sengstaken-Blakemore tube used in the management of bleeding esophageal varices consists of all of the following, except ______.
questions.solution:
The Sengstaken-Blakemore tube consists of 3 channels the esophageal balloon channel, a gastric balloon channel, and a gastric aspiration channel.

The gastric balloon is inflated and tension is applied to the gastroesophageal junction. If this does not control the hemorrhage, the esophageal balloon is inflated as well, compressing the lower oesophageal venous plexus between them. Only gastric contents can be aspirated.

Sengstaken-Blakemore tube is thus used to provide mechanical tamponade for temporary stoppage of bleeding in acute variceal bleed setting.

Linton-Nachlas tube has only two ports and a single gastric balloon. 

The Minnesota tube has 4 openings:

  • Two suction tubes:
    • Gastric aspiration port
    • Esophageal aspiration port
  • Two inflation tubes:
    • Gastric balloon port
    • Esophageal balloon port

This tube allows the aspiration of both gastric and oesophageal contents.

Below is the image of the Minnesota tube.

questions.text: Identify the function of the instrument shown in the image below:
questions.solution:
The instrument shown is a Hegar’s double ended dilator that is used to dilate the cervix in procedures such as dilatation and curettage.

Other options:

Metal catheter used to drain urine is shown below.

Simpson's uterine sound used to measure uterine cavity and cervical length.

Rubin's cannula used in hysterosalpingography.

questions.text: Which of the following is the use and the number of the blade shown in the image?
questions.solution:
The size of the surgical blade shown is the 12-size blade which is a small, pointed, crescent-shaped blade used typically as a suture cutter. It is most sharp on the inside edge of its curve.

Uses of the 11-size blade:

  • Incision and drainage (I & D) of an abscess
  • Insertion of drains and arteriotomy
  • Wound debridement

questions.text: The image given shows a maneuver used during labor. Which of the following forceps can be used instead of this maneuver?
questions.solution:
The image shows Burns-Marshall technique used in the delivery of the aftercoming head in breech delivery. Piper’s forceps can be used to deliver the aftercoming head in breech instead of this maneuver.

Piper's forceps, identified by its distinct perineal curve, is used to assist the delivery of the after-coming head in breech.

It has a cephalic curve, reverse pelvic curve, and long parallel shanks that permit the baby’s body to rest against it during head delivery. It may be applied electively or when the Mauriceau maneuver cannot be accomplished easily.

The image below shows Pipers forceps:


Other options:

Option A: Kielland forceps is a long almost straight (very slight pelvic curve) obstetric forceps without any axis-traction device. It has got a sliding lock which facilitates correction of asynclitism of the head. One small knob on each blade is directed towards the occiput.

Option B: Tucker Mclane forceps: Suitable for fetal head with little molding and in rotational delivery.

Option D: Wrigley's forceps is an outlet forceps. It is used to provide traction force and can also be used in cesarean sections. The instrument is short which is due to a reduction in the length of the shanks and handles. It has a marked cephalic curve with a slight pelvic curve.

Related Pearl: Obstetrics forceps

Commonly used forceps: 

1) Simpson forceps

  • The most commonly used types of forceps in outlet delivery.
  • Has elongated cephalic curve.
  • These are used when there is substantial molding of the fetal head.

2) Elliot forceps

  • Has an adjustable pin for regulating the lateral pressure on the handles.
  • They are used most often when there is minimal molding.
  • More suitable for outlet delivery.

3) Kielland forceps

  • Has small pelvic curve and a sliding lock.
  • Suitable for head with little molding.
  • The most common forceps used for rotational delivery.
  • Helps correct asynclitism.

4) Piper forceps

  • Distinct perineal curve.
  • Allows for application to the after-coming head in breech delivery.

5) Tucker-McLane forceps

  • Suitable for fetal head with little molding.
  • Used in rotational delivery.

6) Barton forceps and traction handle

  • Used in rotational delivery.
  • Most importantly used for delivery of occipitotransverse positions in a platypelloid pelvis.
  • It is an obsolete procedure.

Related Pearl: Maneuvers for breech delivery

Pinard’s manoeuvre 

It is used for the delivery of extended legs in case of breech delivery.

Technique:

  • Flex and abduct the popliteal fossa
  • Catch hold of the ankle
  • Pull down along with abduction

 

Lovset’s manoeuvre

It is used for the delivery of extended arms in case of a breech presentation.

Technique:

  • Hold the sacrum with the thumb, and the hips and pelvis with other fingers.
  • Turn the infant 90 degrees to bring the shoulder under pubic symphysis and deliver the anterior shoulder.
  • Then counter-rotate 180 degrees to engage and deliver the posterior shoulder. 

 

Modified Prague’s manoeuvre

It is used in breech presentations to deliver the aftercoming head when the back of the fetus fails to rotate to the symphysis.

Technique:

  • Grasp the shoulders of the baby from below with two fingers of one hand.
  • Draw the feet up and over the maternal abdomen with the other hand.

 

Burns-Marshall method

It is used for delivery of aftercoming head in case of breech presentation.

Technique:

  • Allow the baby to hang by its own weight.
  • When the nape of the neck is visible under the pubic arch, grasp the baby by the ankles with a finger in between the two.
  • Swing the baby in an arc in an upward and forward direction.

 

Mauriceau-Smellie-Veit technique

It is another method that can be used in the delivery of aftercoming head in case of breech presentation. It is also called malar flexion and shoulder traction.

Technique:

  • Place the baby on the supinated left arm with limbs hanging on either side.
  • Place the index and middle fingers of the left hand on either side over the malar bones.
  • Place the ring and the little finger of the pronated right hand on the child’s right shoulder, index finger on the left shoulder and middle finger over the suboccipital region.
  • Traction is given in the downward and backward direction till the nape of the neck is visible.
  • Thereafter, the baby is carried in an upward and forward direction towards the mother’s abdomen.

 

Mnemonic:

  • Extend the arm to express Love(Lovset's)
  • Put the fingers in popliteal fossa for Pinard's(P for P)

questions.text: While on rounds in the post-operative ward,  you observe your senior teaching a patient who has undergone an open cholecystectomy two days ago, to use this device. What is the main purpose of using this device?
questions.solution:
The purpose of incentive spirometry in a post-operative patient is to prevent pulmonary atelectasis.

Atelectasis, especially of the lower lobes, is the most common respiratory complication in a post-operative patient and can be prevented by sitting the patient or inclining the bed, early mobilization, deep breathing exercises with incentive spirometry, and chest physiotherapy. Patients who are not fully awake may require non-invasive mechanical ventilation with PEEP. Correct manner of performing incentive spirometry is by taking sequential deep breaths so that all the balls or marker in the tube rise to the top, holding the breath for 5-6 seconds, and then exhaling. 

The primary pathophysiology of is inadequate expansion of the alveoli leading to their collapse. The factors predisposing to atelectasis are general anesthesia, upper abdominal and thoracic surgery. In the post-operative period, inadequate pain control may lead to poor inspiratory effort and and reduced diaphragm contraction in the patient's attempt to avoid experiencing pain,  may also contribute to the development of atelectasis. On the other hand, overuse of opioid analgesics or sedatives may also favour development of atelectasis due to respiratory depression causing collection of secretions. Other causes include lack of mobilization (bed-bound patients) or positional change.

Patients present with tachypnoea and decreased oxygen saturation and on examination, the breath sounds are bronchial in nature and reduced in intensity. Chest X-ray may show diminished lung volume, linear opacities, and elevation of the diaphragm on the affected side.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements describe the similarities between Foley's and Malecot's catheters?

1. Both are self-retaining
2. Both are color-coded for size
3. Both are introduced per-urethra
4. Both have a double lumen
5. Both are sized in the ‘French’ scale
questions.solution:
Both Foley's and Malecot's catheters are self-retaining (Option 1) and sized in the ‘French’ scale (Option 5).

However, a Foley's catheter is color coded for size (Option 2), can be introduced per-urethra (Option 3) and may have a double lumen (Option 4), none of which are true for a Malecot catheter.

A Foley catheter is a self-retaining sterile, latex tube with a straight tip that is used to drain urine and may be introduced per urethra. The key feature is the presence of a balloon at the tip which is inflatable, making the catheter retained at the neck of the bladder. The size of the Foley catheter is based on the outer diameter in mm according to the ‘French’ scale (1 Fr = 0.3mm) according to which the catheter is color coded. Foley catheters have one lumen for draining urine, and one for instilling sterile water for bladder inflation in the case of two-way Foley, while a three-way Foley also has another lumen for irrigation.


A Malecot's catheter on the other hand is made of red rubber and is self-retaining because of its characteristic flower/umbrella tip. It has a single lumen for drainage. It is also sized according to the French scale but has no color coding. It cannot be introduced per-urethra but may be used in suprapubic cystostomy or other urinary diversion procedures, and also for drainage of pus from abscess cavities.

Related Pearl: Foley's Catheter

A Foley catheter is a thin, sterile tube inserted into the bladder to drain urine. Because it can be left in place in the bladder for a period of time, it is also called an indwelling catheter.

French scale corresponds to the outer diameter in millimetres, and 1Fr is 0.3 mm in diameter.

Fr. size = 3 x d, where d is the outer diameter in mm. 

A 18 Fr. catheter will have a circumference of approximately 18 mm and a diameter of 6 mm. 

Note:

Colour of the foleys is the colour at the baloon port as shown in the figure below

questions.text:
A patient in the ICU, who was in a comatose condition, was shifted onto the ventilator for assisted ventilation. Which of the following circuits will be used in this condition?

Fresh gas flow - Blue 

Adjustable pressure-limiting (APL) valve - Red
questions.solution:
The patient in the given case scenario would be put on controlled ventilation. The most appropriate circuit to be used in this case is the Mapleson D circuit which is depicted in image 2, since it is one of the most efficacious circuits for controlled ventilation. Modification of Mapleson D is known as the Bain circuit.

The order of efficiency for controlled ventilation amongst Mapleson circuits is DFE>BC>A.

Image 2 is identified as the Mapleson D circuit due to the following observations:

  • Fresh gas flow (blue) is near the patient's mouth
  • APL valve(red) is away from the patient's mouth
  • Presence of a reservoir bag distal to APL valve.

The Mapleson D circuit is efficient during controlled ventilation since it has a very low requirement of fresh gas flow in terms of minute ventilation (only 1-2 times the minute ventilation). In this circuit, the fresh gas flow forces alveolar air away from the patient and toward the APL valve. 

The Bain circuit is a coaxial version of the Mapleson D system that incorporates the fresh gas inlet tubing inside the breathing tube. This modification decreases the circuit’s bulk and retains heat and humidity better than a conventional Mapleson D circuit as a result of partial warming of the inspiratory gas by countercurrent exchange with the warmer expired gases.

The order of efficiency for spontaneous ventilation amongst Mapleson circuits is A>DFE> CB.

Other options: 

Option B - Image 1 is identified as Mapleson A. It is the most efficacious for use in spontaneous ventilation.

Option C - Image 4 is identified as Mapleson B. This circuit is less efficacious than Mapleson D in controlled ventilation.

Option D - Image 3 is identified as Mapleson F. This circuit is less efficacious than Mapleson D in controlled ventilation.

Related Pearl: Mapleson Classification

Mapleson circuit   Other name  Fresh gas flow rate
Spontaneous ventilation  Controlled ventilation
A Magills 1 minute ventilation (MV) i.e. 80 ml/kg/min Very high and difficult to predict
B - 2-3× (MV) 2-2.5 × (MV)
C Water’s to and fro 2-3 × (MV) 2-2.5 × (MV)
D Bain circuit 2-3 × (MV) 1-2 × (MV)
E Ayre’s t-piece 2-3 × (MV) 3 × (MV)
F Jackson rees modification 2-3 × (MV) 2 × (MV)

 

Note:

The efficiency of Mapleson circuits in spontaneous ventilation is  A > DFE > CB (A Dog Can Bite - Usually a spontaneous event)

The efficiency of Mapleson circuits in controlled ventilation is DFE > BC > A (Dead Babies can't assist - controlled)



Related Pearl: Identification of Mapleson's circuits

Mapleson System

 Fresh gas flow inlet APL valve location Reservoir bag Corrugated tubing Example and comments
A Near bag Near patient Present Present

Magill;

Lack (co-axial) 
B Near patient Near patient Present Present Obsolete
C Near patient Near patient Present Absent Obsolete; Still used in emergency resuscitation (AMBU bag)
D Near patient Away from patient Present Present Bain (co-axial)
E Near patient Absent Absent Present Ayre's T piece
F Near patient Absent Present Present Jackson Rees Modification for pediatric patients

questions.text: Which of the following retractors is best suited for retracting the skin flap during sebaceous cyst excision?
questions.solution:
A double hook retractor (Image 3)  is best suited for retracting the skin flap during sebaceous cyst excision.

Uses of a double hook retractor (shown below):

  • To retract skin flap during sebaceous cyst excision. 
  • Skin retraction during venesection. 
  • Skin and thyroid isthmus retraction during tracheostomy.


Image 1: Travers retractor (shown below) is a self-retaining retractor. It is used to retract the skin and subcutaneous tissues during intermediate-type operations, such as 

  • Herniorrhaphy
  • Groin dissection for varicose veins
  • Femoral embolectomy

Incorrect usage can traumatize the skin - the retractor has to be repositioned as the incision is deepened.


Image 2: Czerny's retractor (shown below) is a double-ended retractor with two prongs on one end and a blade with a lip on the other. It is used during laparotomy for superficial skin retraction.


Image 4: Mollison’s mastoid retractor (shown below) is self-retaining and hemostatic. It is used in mastoidectomy to retract soft tissues.

Related Pearl: Identification of Surgical Retractors

Deaver's Retractor:

Doyen's retractor:

Morris retractor:

Czerny’s retractor:

questions.text: A 28-year-old primigravida who was admitted to the labor room at 40 weeks of gestation was planned for induction of labor using the device shown below. Which of the following medications is present in this device?
questions.solution:
The obstetric device shown in the above image is of cervidil vaginal insert. It contains 10 mg of dinoprostone.

A cervidil vaginal insert is a thin, flat, rectangular polymeric wafer held within a small, white mesh polyester sac. It contains 10 mg of dinoprostone (PGE2) released at a rate of 0.3 mg/hour. The sac has a long attached tail to allow easy removal from the vagina.

Following insertion, the woman should remain recumbent for at least 2 hours. The insert is removed after 12 hours or with labor onset and at least 30 minutes before the administration of oxytocin.

It is used for cervical ripening prior to induction. A possible side effect of dinoprostone is uterine tachysystole.

Related Pearl: Indications & contraindications for induction of labor

Indications:
  • Uncontrolled maternal diabetes mellitus
  • Gestational hypertension
  • Pre-eclampsia
  • Post-term pregnancy
  • Abruption placentae
  • Premature rupture of membranes
  • Rh-isoimmunization
  • Intra-uterine growth restriction (IUGR)
  • Intra-uterine death (IUD)
  • Oligohydramnios
Contraindications:
  • Contracted/distorted pelvis and cephalopelvic disproportion
  • Placenta previa or vasa previa
  • Active genital herpes
  • Pelvic tumor & carcinoma cervix
  • Transverse lie or footling breech
  • Appreciable macrosomia
  • Severe hydrocephalus
  • Umbilical cord prolapse
  • High-risk pregnancy with fetal compromise
  • Previous classical cesarean or hysterotomy
  • Previous history of uterine rupture
  • Pelvic surgeries like vesicovaginal fistula/rectovaginal fistula/pelvic floor repair (third or fourth-degree perineal tears repair)
  • Previous 3 or more lower transverse cesarian sections.

questions.text: What is the best position for the patient to be in while inserting the given tube for enteral feeds?
questions.solution:
The given image is Ryle's tube. The best position for this patient during the insertion of Ryle's tube is sitting with neck flexion.

Nasogastric tube/ Ryle's tube is used to provide enteral feeds. It is also used to diagnose the patency of the esophagus in conditions like tracheoesophageal fistula. If enteral feeds are continued for more than a week then a fine bore tube is used. 

It is inserted by standing perpendicular to the patient and the distance is calculated using the NEX method.

NEX method:
  • The tip of the nose to ear to xiphisternum.
  • The tube length should be estimated before insertion.
  • Place the exit port of the tube at the tip of the nose. Extend tube to the earlobe, and then to xiphisternum.

Confirmation of the correct position is done by auscultation in the epigastric area while injecting a bolus of air and X-ray chest. 

Approximate length: 120-125 cm

Markings indicating traversing of the tube through various parts of the stomach:

1) 40 cm - Traversed cardia of the stomach

2) 50 cm - Traversed body of stomach

3) 60 cm - Traversed pylorus

4) 70 cm - Tube has traversed Duodenum

Indications for NG tube:

  • Aspiration of gastric fluid
  • Gastric decompression in cases of intestinal obstruction and paralytic ileus.
  • Zollinger-Ellison syndrome is characterized by hypersecretion of gastrin resulting in acid-induced diarrhea that is controlled by nasogastric aspiration of gastric secretions 
  • Feeding
  • Administration of medication
  • Bowel irrigation

Contraindications for NG tube:

  • Absolute:
    • Severe midface trauma
    • Recent nasal surgery
    • Basilar skull fractures
  • Relative:
    • Coagulation abnormality
    • Caustic ingestion
    • Esophageal trauma/ obstruction
    • Esophageal varices
    • Recent banding of esophageal varices
    • Anastomoses in the stomach and esophagus

questions.text: Identify the instrument.
questions.solution:
The given image is that of Kocher forceps. It can be identified by the presence of serrations in the blade and apposing tooth in the tips.

It is used to hold the gauze for blunt dissection, to hold the resected bowel, and to hold the ribs during rib resection. 

Other options:

Option A - Babcock forceps:

  • The distal part of the distal blade is curved with a triangular opening which allows soft tissues to bulge out.
  • The tip is non-traumatic with transverse serrations on it.
  • It has got a lock in the proximal part.
  • It is used to hold any part of the bowel, fallopian tube, appendix, ureter, cord, etc.


Option C - Lane tissue-holding forceps:

  • It has stout and thick distal blades, with an oval opening in each blade.
  • The tips have apposing tooth with a lock in the proximal part of the instrument
  • It is used to hold bulky and tough structures and hold lymph nodes.


Option D - Lister sinus forceps:

  • It has straight long blades with serrations in the tip.
  • It is used to drain pus during Hilton's method of abscess drainage to break the bacterial loculi.
  • It is used for inserting or removing packing in the sinus cavity.

Related Pearl: Instruments in OBG

Related Pearl: Orthopedic Instruments

questions.text: Identify the instrument given below. Which of the following structures is not cut during the procedure most commonly carried out by this instrument?

choices.text: Transverse perineal branches of pudendal  nerves

questions.solution:
The instrument in the given image is an episiotomy scissors. The obturator muscle is not cut during mediolateral episiotomy which is the most commonly done procedure using this instrument.

A surgically planned incision on the perineum and the posterior vaginal wall during the second stage of labour is called an episiotomy. In mediolateral episiotomy, the incision is made downwards and outwards from the midpoint of the fourchette either to the right or to the left.

Structures cut in mediolateral episiotomy:

  • Posterior vaginal wall
  • Superficial and deep transverse perineal muscles
  • Bulbospongiosus and part of levator ani
  • Fascia covering these muscles
  • Transverse perineal branches of pudendal vessels and nerves
  • Subcutaneous tissue and skin

The other types of episiotomy include median, lateral, and J shaped episiotomy.

Related Pearl: Mediolateral Episiotomy

It begins within 3 mm of the midline in the posterior fourchette and is directed laterally at an angle of at least 60 degrees from the midline. This yields an incision of 45 degrees off the midline.

It is essentially an inflicted second-degree perineal tear.

Structures cut in mediolateral episiotomy:

  • Posterior vaginal wall
  • Superficial and deep transverse perineal muscles, bulbospongiosus and part of levator ani
  • Fascia covering those muscles
  • Transverse perineal branches of pudendal vessels and nerves
  • Subcutaneous tissue and skin

Advantage: Lesser risk of anal sphincter laceration, hence it is preferred over median episiotomy.

Disadvantage: Increased blood loss and causes more perineal pain and dyspareunia.

Related Pearl: Instruments in OBG

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding the procedure performed with the given instrument?

choices.text: Used during injection sclerotherapy for hemorrhoids
Can be done without prior digital rectal examination
Can be done in a patient with acute anal fissure
Lower part of sigmoid colon can be visualised

questions.solution:
The given image shows a proctoscope, used for performing proctoscopy. One of the therapeutic indications of proctoscopy is performing injection sclerotherapy of hemorrhoids.

Proctoscopy can be used to inspect the anus, anorectal junction and the lower part of the rectum (option D). Most commonly the patient is examined in the left lateral (Sims) position with the buttocks overlying the edge of the examination couch. Alternatively in younger patients, prone jack-knife or knee-elbow positions may be used. A digital rectal examination is mandatory before performing a proctoscopy (option B). Minor procedures such as injection sclerotherapy or banding of hemorrhoids and biopsy of suspected neoplasms can also be carried out in conjunction with proctoscopy (option A). Acute anal fissure is a contraindication for doing proctoscopy (option C) because it is extremely painful for the patient.

questions.text: When asked to give the Sims curette, you would pick:
questions.solution:
The instrument marked as 1 in the image is Sims curette. It is a single-ended uterine curette used for dilatation and curettage.

It is designed to remove tough tissue from the lining of the uterus for biopsy or excision. The curette features a sharp loop tip to aid in the removal of uterine tissue.

Dilatation and curettage:

Instruments used in D&C:

  • Sims speculum: It retracts the posterior vaginal wall to expose the cervix
  • Anterior vaginal wall retractor: Retracts the anterior vaginal wall to expose the cervix
  • Vulsellum or Allis forceps: To hold the anterior lip of the cervix
  • Uterine sound: Simpson's uterine sound is a 30 cm long angulated instrument with a handle at one end and a rounded blunt tip at the other
    It is used to measure the length of the uterus. It can be identified by the markings used for measurement
  • Cervical dilators: 
    • Hegar dilator is a double-ended dilator used to dilate the cervix.
    • Hawkins’ single-ended dilator 
    • Fenton’s dilator
  • Curette:
    • Sims curette is a single-ended curette
    • Blake's curette is a double-ended curette


The image above shows the trolley with various instruments:

  1. Sims uterine curette
  2. Hegar dilator
  3. Sims uterine sound
  4. Karman's cannula - It is used for menstrual regulation. It can be identified by the whistle-like tip.
  5. Leech Wilkinson's cannula
  6. Rubin's cannula 

Leech Wilkinson's cannula and Rubin's cannula are used in hysterosalpingography.

Related Pearl: Instruments in OBG
